title: Romans Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:3, what was counted to Abraham for righteousness?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:3 states that Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:5 say is counted for righteousness?
options: Faith in God who justifies the ungodly
questions.correctAnswer: Faith in God who justifies the ungodly
questions.explanation: Romans 4:5 explains that to him who works not but believes on God who justifies the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 4:2 says that Abraham was justified by works before God.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:2 clearly states Abraham was not justified before God by works.

questions.question: Who is described in Romans 4:6 as blessed, having righteousness imputed without works?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:6 says David also describes the blessedness of the man to whom God imputes righteousness without works.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Romans 4:7: 'Blessed are they whose ______ are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.'
questions.explanation: Romans 4:7 states, 'Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.'

questions.question: Romans 4:9 asks if blessedness comes upon which group?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:9 questions whether blessedness is only for circumcision or also for uncircumcision, affirming both by faith.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:11, what did Abraham receive as a seal of righteousness of faith?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:11 states Abraham received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness of faith he had while uncircumcised.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 4:13 says the promise to Abraham was through the law.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:13 clearly states the promise was not through the law but through the righteousness of faith.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:15 say the law works?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:15 explains that the law works wrath; where there is no law, there is no transgression.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:16, faith is by what means?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:16 states that it is of faith so it might be by grace to ensure the promise to all the seed.

questions.question: Who is called the father of many nations in Romans 4:17?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:17 says Abraham is the father of many nations, whom he believed, even God.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 4:20 says Abraham staggered at the promise of God through unbelief.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:20 states Abraham did not stagger at the promise of God through unbelief but was strong in faith.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:22, what was imputed to Abraham for righteousness?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:22 confirms that faith was imputed to Abraham for righteousness.

questions.question: To whom else does Romans 4:24 say righteousness will be imputed if they believe?
options: Us who believe in Him that raised Jesus from the dead
Those who keep the law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Us who believe in Him that raised Jesus from the dead
questions.explanation: Romans 4:24 states righteousness will be imputed to us also if we believe on Him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.

questions.question: Who was delivered for our offences and raised again for our justification according to Romans 4:25?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:25 says Jesus was delivered for our offences and raised again for our justification.

medium.title: Romans Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 teach us about the basis of righteousness in Christian living?
options: Righteousness is counted by faith, not by works
Righteousness comes only through strict law-keeping
Righteousness is earned by good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness is counted by faith, not by works
questions.explanation: Romans 4:3, 4:5, and 4:13 emphasize that Abraham was counted righteous because of his faith, not his works or adherence to the law. This teaches that faith is the key to righteousness.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel their works do not justify them before God. Based on Romans 4, what truth would you share?
options: Justification comes through faith, not by works
Only perfect works can justify before God
Law-keeping is the only way to be justified
questions.correctAnswer: Justification comes through faith, not by works
questions.explanation: Romans 4:2, 4:4, and 4:5 teach that justification is by faith, not by works, and faith is credited as righteousness, offering hope to those discouraged by their works.

questions.question: According to Romans 4, how does God treat the sins of those who have faith?
options: God forgives and does not impute sin to them
God remembers their sins to discipline them
God only forgives after strict penance
questions.correctAnswer: God forgives and does not impute sin to them
questions.explanation: Romans 4:7-8 explains that blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven and whose sins are not counted against them, showing God's grace toward believers.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 encourage believers to trust God when facing seemingly impossible situations?
options: By remembering Abraham’s faith despite impossible odds
By relying on their own strength and wisdom
By seeking reassurance only from friends
By giving up if circumstances are too difficult
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering Abraham’s faith despite impossible odds
questions.explanation: Romans 4:18-20 highlights Abraham’s unwavering faith despite his old age and Sarah’s barrenness, encouraging believers to trust God’s promises in trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God’s promises. What example from Romans 4 would you share to encourage perseverance in faith?
options: Abraham did not stagger at the promise through unbelief but was strong in faith
David demanded signs before believing God
Abraham relied on his works to gain righteousness
Faith is unnecessary if the law is kept
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham did not stagger at the promise through unbelief but was strong in faith
questions.explanation: Romans 4:20-21 shows Abraham’s steadfast trust and glorifying God, illustrating how believers should maintain faith despite doubts.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 guide us in understanding the role of faith and the law in receiving God’s promises?
options: Promises come through faith, not through the law
The law is the only way to inherit the promises
Faith is unnecessary if the law is followed
Promises are given only to the circumcised
questions.correctAnswer: Promises come through faith, not through the law
questions.explanation: Romans 4:13-15 explains that the promise to Abraham and his seed is through righteousness of faith, not law, emphasizing grace over law for heirs of the promise.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 encourage humility in Christian living regarding works and grace?
options: Those who work receive a reward as a debt, not as grace
We should boast in our works before God
Grace is given only to those who earn it
questions.correctAnswer: Those who work receive a reward as a debt, not as grace
questions.explanation: Romans 4:4 teaches that a worker’s reward is not grace but debt, encouraging believers to humbly rely on God’s grace rather than their own merit.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 4, Abraham was justified after he was circumcised.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:10-11 states that Abraham’s faith was reckoned as righteousness before he was circumcised, showing justification precedes physical signs.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 4 teaches that the promise of inheriting the world is given only to those who follow the law perfectly.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:14-16 explains that if heirs were only those under the law, faith would be void and promise nullified. The promise is sure through faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Who was delivered for our offenses, and was raised again for our ________."
questions.explanation: Romans 4:25 clearly states Jesus was delivered for our offenses and raised for our justification, affirming the basis of Christian hope.

questions.question: How can Romans 4 help a believer understand the importance of faith in evangelism?
options: Faith is the key to righteousness and inheriting God’s promises, which is foundational to sharing the Gospel
Good works alone qualify one to evangelize
Only those circumcised can share the Gospel
questions.correctAnswer: Faith is the key to righteousness and inheriting God’s promises, which is foundational to sharing the Gospel
questions.explanation: Romans 4:3, 4:16 teach faith as the root of righteousness and promise, enabling believers to witness confidently about salvation by faith.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God’s power and faith can be shared with someone facing physical or spiritual barrenness?
options: God calls things that are not as though they were
God limits His promises to the natural realm
questions.correctAnswer: God calls things that are not as though they were
questions.explanation: Romans 4:17 describes God’s power to give life and call things into existence, encouraging trust in His supernatural ability.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 instruct believers about receiving God’s promises for all people, not just a select group?
options: The promise is sure to all who share Abraham’s faith, not only those under the law
The promise is only for Jews who keep the law
Non-circumcised people cannot receive the promise
The promise depends on ethnic lineage
questions.correctAnswer: The promise is sure to all who share Abraham’s faith, not only those under the law
questions.explanation: Romans 4:16, 4:12 show Abraham as father of all who believe, whether circumcised or not, emphasizing faith’s inclusiveness.

questions.question: According to Romans 4, how should believers respond when God’s promises seem delayed or impossible?
options: By continuing strong in faith and giving glory to God
By doubting and giving up hope
By trying to earn the promise through works
questions.correctAnswer: By continuing strong in faith and giving glory to God
questions.explanation: Romans 4:20 encourages believers not to stagger through unbelief but to be strong in faith, glorifying God despite delays.

questions.question: How does Romans 4 guide believers in understanding the relationship between faith and grace in their spiritual walk?
options: Faith is the means by which grace is received and promises are assured
Grace is earned by strict observance of the law
Faith is unnecessary if grace is given
Grace depends on works, not faith
questions.correctAnswer: Faith is the means by which grace is received and promises are assured
questions.explanation: Romans 4:16 teaches that faith enables grace and ensures the promise to all Abraham’s seed, pointing to reliance on God’s unmerited favor.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to Romans 4, what is the basis for Abraham being counted as righteous?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:3 states, 'Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness,' emphasizing faith as the basis for righteousness rather than works.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:4 say about the reward given to someone who works?
options: It is given as a gift
It is counted as a debt
questions.correctAnswer: It is counted as a debt
questions.explanation: Romans 4:4 explains that the reward for work is not a matter of grace but is owed as a debt, underscoring the difference between grace and works.

questions.question: Romans 4 draws a parallel between Abraham's faith and the faith of which Old Testament figure?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:6-8 quotes David describing the blessedness of a man to whom God imputes righteousness without works, connecting Abraham’s faith to David’s testimony.

questions.question: In Romans 4:9-10, was Abraham's faith reckoned for righteousness before or after his circumcision?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:10 clearly states Abraham's faith was reckoned for righteousness when he was uncircumcised, highlighting the primacy of faith over the law.

questions.question: What is the significance of circumcision in Romans 4:11 according to Paul's argument?
options: It is a sign of covenant only for Jews
A seal of righteousness of the faith Abraham had before circumcision
A symbol of the law's supremacy
questions.correctAnswer: A seal of righteousness of the faith Abraham had before circumcision
questions.explanation: Romans 4:11 explains circumcision as a seal confirming the righteousness that Abraham had by faith while uncircumcised, serving as a typology for all believers.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:13, how was the promise to Abraham about being heir of the world fulfilled?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:13 clarifies that the promise was given through faith's righteousness, not via law, emphasizing faith’s central role in Abraham’s inheritance.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:14 say about the relationship between law and faith?
options: If heirs are of the law, faith is nullified
questions.correctAnswer: If heirs are of the law, faith is nullified
questions.explanation: Romans 4:14 states that if those under the law are heirs, then faith becomes void and the promise is ineffective, contrasting law and faith.

questions.question: Romans 4:15 explains that the law works what effect?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:15 teaches that the law brings wrath because where there is no law, there is no transgression, highlighting the law’s role in revealing sin.

questions.question: Why does Paul say in Romans 4:16 that the promise is made sure to all Abraham’s seed?
options: Because it is by faith and grace
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is by faith and grace
questions.explanation: Romans 4:16 declares the promise is by faith to ensure it is by grace and sure to all the seed, not only those under the law, emphasizing inclusivity.

questions.question: What divine attribute is highlighted in Romans 4:17 in relation to Abraham’s faith?
options: God who quickens the dead and calls things that are not as though they were
questions.correctAnswer: God who quickens the dead and calls things that are not as though they were
questions.explanation: Romans 4:17 emphasizes God’s power to give life to the dead and to call into existence the non-existent, underpinning Abraham’s hope.

questions.question: How does Romans 4:18 describe Abraham’s hope?
options: He hoped because of the law
He hoped because of his works
questions.explanation: Romans 4:18 states Abraham believed in hope against hope, showing his unwavering faith despite seemingly impossible circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 4:19-20, Abraham was weak in faith because of his and Sarah's old age.
questions.explanation: Romans 4:19-20 clarifies Abraham was not weak in faith; he did not doubt God’s promise despite his and Sarah’s old age, showing strong faith.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:21 say about Abraham's confidence in God’s promise?
options: He was fully persuaded God could perform what He promised
questions.correctAnswer: He was fully persuaded God could perform what He promised
questions.explanation: Romans 4:21 notes Abraham was fully convinced that God was able to fulfill His promise, demonstrating strong conviction and trust.

questions.question: Romans 4:24 connects Abraham's righteousness being imputed to whom else?
options: To all who believe in God who raised Jesus from the dead
To those who follow the law only
questions.correctAnswer: To all who believe in God who raised Jesus from the dead
questions.explanation: Romans 4:24 teaches that righteousness is imputed to believers who trust in God’s power to raise Jesus, linking Old Testament faith with New Testament justification.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Jesus' resurrection as stated in Romans 4:25?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:25 reveals Jesus was raised for our justification, indicating resurrection as the basis for believers’ right standing before God.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 4, how was Abraham justified before God?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:3 clearly states that Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness. This principle is consistent with Habakkuk 2:4 where the righteous shall live by faith, and also with Galatians 3:6 and James 2:23 which affirm faith as the basis of righteousness.

questions.question: What does Romans 4:4 say about the reward for work?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:4 explains that to the one who works, the reward is not reckoned by grace but as a debt. This aligns with Exodus 20:12-13 where law requires payment for transgression, and with Ephesians 2:8-9 contrasting grace and works.

questions.question: Who is justified according to Romans 4:5?
options: He who does not work but believes in God
He who follows the law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: He who does not work but believes in God
questions.explanation: Romans 4:5 states that the one who does not work but believes on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness. This is consistent with Psalm 32:1-2 and Isaiah 53:11, and echoes New Testament teaching in John 3:16 and Galatians 2:16.

questions.question: What blessing does David describe in Romans 4:7-8?
options: Blessed are those who obey the law
Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven
questions.explanation: Romans 4:7-8 quotes David describing the blessedness of those whose sins are forgiven and to whom the Lord will not impute sin. This reflects Psalm 32:1-2 and Isaiah 1:18 and aligns with New Testament themes in Hebrews 10:17 and 1 John 1:9.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:9-10, was Abraham's faith reckoned to him before or after circumcision?
options: Only after the law was given
questions.explanation: Romans 4:10 teaches that Abraham's faith was reckoned to him while he was still uncircumcised, showing that righteousness by faith precedes the law and covenant signs. This corresponds with Genesis 15:6 and Galatians 3:6-9 emphasizing faith before law.

questions.question: What is the significance of Abraham receiving circumcision as described in Romans 4:11?
options: It was a requirement for justification
It was a seal of the righteousness of faith
It was the cause of his righteousness
It was a symbol of the law
questions.correctAnswer: It was a seal of the righteousness of faith
questions.explanation: Romans 4:11 teaches that circumcision was a seal of the righteousness Abraham had by faith before being circumcised, signifying the inclusion of all believers, circumcised or not. This complements Genesis 17:10-11 and Colossians 2:11-12.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:13, how was the promise to Abraham and his seed to be received?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:13 states the promise that Abraham would be heir of the world was not through the law but through the righteousness of faith, echoing Genesis 15:5-6 and Galatians 3:16-18 concerning the promise given by faith, not law.

questions.question: What happens to faith if inheritance is based on the law, according to Romans 4:14?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:14 explains that if heirs are of the law, then faith is made void and the promise is nullified, consistent with Galatians 3:10-14 and Hebrews 7:18-19 which show the law's inability to justify.

questions.question: What role does grace play in the promise according to Romans 4:16?
options: It ensures the promise is sure
It is only for the Jewish people
questions.correctAnswer: It ensures the promise is sure
questions.explanation: Romans 4:16 teaches that the promise is received through faith so it may be by grace, ensuring it is sure to all Abraham's seed, Jew and Gentile alike. This reflects Ephesians 2:8-9 and Titus 3:5 about grace through faith.

questions.question: How does Romans 4:17 portray God's power in relation to Abraham's faith?
options: God only calls things that exist
God calls things that do not exist as though they were
God works only through the law
questions.correctAnswer: God calls things that do not exist as though they were
questions.explanation: Romans 4:17 illustrates God's sovereign power to call into existence what does not yet exist, affirming the creative power of God and the basis for Abraham's hope, which corresponds to Genesis 17:5 and John 1:3.

questions.question: What attitude did Abraham demonstrate toward the promise despite natural circumstances, according to Romans 4:18-19?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:18-19 describes Abraham’s faith as believing against hope, not considering his own dead body or Sarah's dead womb, paralleling Genesis 21:1-2 and Hebrews 11:11, highlighting the power of faith over natural impossibilities.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:20-21, what was Abraham’s reaction to God’s promise?
options: He glorified God and was fully persuaded
questions.correctAnswer: He glorified God and was fully persuaded
questions.explanation: Romans 4:20-21 shows Abraham did not stagger through unbelief but was strong in faith, giving glory to God and being fully persuaded that God could fulfill His promise. This aligns with Psalm 22:3 and Hebrews 11:17-19.

questions.question: Why was Abraham’s faith imputed to him for righteousness according to Romans 4:22?
options: Because he believed God who justifies the ungodly
questions.correctAnswer: Because he believed God who justifies the ungodly
questions.explanation: Romans 4:22 confirms that Abraham’s faith was imputed as righteousness because he believed God, who justifies the ungodly. This corresponds with Genesis 15:6, and also with 2 Corinthians 5:21 and Galatians 3:13-14.

questions.question: Who else benefits from the imputation of righteousness besides Abraham, according to Romans 4:23-24?
options: All who believe in God who raised Jesus from the dead
Only those who keep the law
questions.correctAnswer: All who believe in God who raised Jesus from the dead
questions.explanation: Romans 4:23-24 teaches that righteousness is imputed not only to Abraham but also to us who believe in God, who raised Jesus from the dead, emphasizing faith in the resurrection as the basis for justification. This aligns with 1 Corinthians 15:17 and Philippians 3:9.

questions.question: According to Romans 4:25, what is the purpose of Jesus’ resurrection?
questions.explanation: Romans 4:25 states Jesus was raised again for our justification, showing the resurrection's essential role in securing believers’ righteousness before God. This is consistent with 1 Corinthians 15:17 and Romans 5:1.
